title: 111_hr3737
content: The Act may be cited as the "Small Business Microlending Expansion Act of 2009". It includes a Microloan Credit Building Initiative. Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act is amended to require intermediaries to provide credit reporting information to major credit agencies for borrowers receiving loans under this subsection. Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act is amended to require intermediaries to provide credit reporting information to major credit agencies for borrowers receiving loans under this subsection. This information can be provided through the Administration or independently. SEC. 3. FLEXIBLE CREDIT TERMS. Amends Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act to remove "short-term" from certain paragraphs. SEC. 4. INCREASED PROGRAM PARTICIPATION. Section 7(m)(2) of the Small Business Act is amended to require experience in making microloans to small businesses. The Small Business Act now requires a minimum of 3 years of experience in making microloans to small businesses, along with 1 year of providing intensive marketing, management, and technical assistance to borrowers or having 1 full-time employee with this experience. The Small Business Act now requires 1 full-time employee with at least 1 year of experience providing intensive marketing, management, and technical assistance to borrowers. SEC. 5 increases the limit on intermediary borrowing from $750,000 to $1,000,000 and from $3,500,000 to $7,000,000. The Administrator may consider $7,000,000 as $10,000,000 if deemed appropriate. SEC. 6 expands borrower education assistance. SEC. 6 expands borrower education assistance by increasing the percentage from 25% to 35% in the Small Business Act. Section 7(m)(4) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Young Entrepreneurs Program for providing technical assistance to young entrepreneurs in establishing or operating small businesses. The Young Entrepreneurs Program offers technical assistance to young entrepreneurs aged 25 or younger residing in a specific geographic area to acquire financing for their small business activities. The Young Entrepreneurs Program requires young entrepreneurs to have resided in the geographic area served by the intermediary for at least 2 years. Additionally, if they establish or operate a small business concern with technical assistance from the intermediary, they must make a good faith effort to do so in the same geographic area. Young entrepreneurs receiving a loan under the Young Entrepreneurs Program can defer repayment for up to 6 months after receiving the final disbursement. SEC. 8. INTEREST RATES AND LOAN SIZE amended to increase loan size from $7,500 to $10,000. SEC. 9. REPORTING REQUIREMENT. Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a reporting requirement for the Administrator to submit an annual report to the Committees on Small Business regarding the microloan program. The annual report on the microloan program must include details on funds received by intermediaries for microloans, marketing, management, and technical assistance. It should also cover loan and grant amounts, non-Federal contributions, and the number and amounts of microloans made to women entrepreneurs and business owners. The annual report on the microloan program includes details on funds received by intermediaries for microloans, marketing, management, and technical assistance provided to various groups such as women, low-income, veteran, disabled, and minority entrepreneurs and business owners. The annual report on the microloan program details funds received by intermediaries for microloans and assistance provided to women, low-income, veteran, disabled, and minority entrepreneurs. It also includes information on the number of jobs created and retained. The annual report on the microloan program includes details on funds received by intermediaries, assistance provided to various entrepreneurs, job creation and retention, repayment history, and success of businesses after receiving microloans. SEC. 10. Surplus interest rate subsidy for businesses. The Administrator can provide grants to intermediaries to reduce interest rates for borrowers under this subsection. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations. Section 20 of the Small Business Act is amended to authorize the Administration to provide $80 million in technical assistance grants, $110 million in direct loans, and $10 million in interest assistance grants for fiscal years 2010 and 2011 under section 7(m). Authorization of appropriations is provided in section 7(m)(16) for necessary funds to carry out the provisions. SEC. 12. REGULATIONS. The Administrator must issue regulations within 180 days of the enactment of this Act to carry out its provisions. Passed the House of Representatives on November 7, 2009.
